title: 105_hr1337
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Haskell Indian Nations University and Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute Administrative Systems Act of 1997". The Congress finds that providing culturally sensitive curricula for higher education programs at Haskell Indian Nations University and the Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute aligns with the Federal Government's commitment to fulfilling treaty obligations to Indian tribes through self-determination and Federal resources. Granting more autonomy to these institutions, while keeping them part of the Bureau of Indian Affairs, will aid in transitioning Haskell to a 4-year university and enhancing the academic program at the Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS.

(1) Haskell Indian Nations University: Haskell Indian Nations University in Lawrence, Kansas.
(2) Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute: Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute in Albuquerque, New Mexico.
(3) Respective institutions: Haskell Indian Nations University and Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute.
(4) Secretary: Secretary of the Interior.

SEC. 4. PERSONNEL MANAGEMENT. The Act exempts certain civil service laws and provides alternative personnel management provisions for Haskell Indian Nations University and Southwestern Indian Polytechnic Institute. The presidents of these institutions can establish necessary regulations for effective administration. The regulations under this subsection must be prescribed in consultation with the institution's governing body, comply with specific procedural requirements, and receive prior approval from the Secretary before taking effect. Additionally, specific substantive requirements limit the maximum rate of basic pay for employees. The regulations must comply with procedural requirements and receive approval from the Secretary before taking effect. The maximum rate of basic pay for employees is limited under specific substantive requirements. Section 5307 of title 5, United States Code applies with necessary modifications. Procedures for grievance resolution, notice and hearing requirements for employee discharge, and notification of employment agreement renewal at least 30 days prior to the end of the period. The employment agreement will be renewed without affecting equal employment opportunity, Indian preference, veterans' preference, merit system principles, prohibited personnel practices, or labor-management provisions. Any existing collective-bargaining agreements will continue as is. The Act does not impact labor organizations' right to exclusive representation or existing collective bargaining agreements. Alternative personnel management provisions will take effect as specified in regulations. The alternative personnel management provisions under this section shall apply to all applicants and employees of the institution involved, with specific effective dates specified. The alternative personnel management provisions apply to all institution employees with specified effective dates. Employees have a 5-year period to elect coverage under these provisions, with irrevocable procedures for making the election. Any individual who elects under paragraph (2) or is transferred, promoted, or reappointed to a position within an institution covered by this Act from a position in the Federal Government or the government of the District of Columbia, will be credited with annual and sick leave as per section 6308 of title 5, United States Code. Upon termination of employment with an institution covered by this Act, any remaining annual and sick leave will be liquidated according to relevant sections of title 5, United States Code. Upon termination of employment with an institution covered by this Act, any remaining sick leave will be creditable for civil service retirement purposes, except for leave earned under specific regulations. In cases of transfer, promotion, or reemployment within the same institution without a break in service, remaining leave will also be transferred. Upon termination of employment with an institution covered by this Act, any remaining sick leave will be creditable for civil service retirement purposes, except for leave earned under specific regulations. In cases of transfer, promotion, or reemployment within the same institution without a break in service, remaining leave will also be transferred. For service of 3 days or longer in the Federal Government or the government of the District of Columbia under a different leave system, any remaining leave earned under regulations prescribed under this section shall be transferred to the individual's credit in the employing agency on an adjusted basis. Work-study students are excluded from this provision. The Secretary can delegate procurement authority to institution presidents. Each institution is authorized appropriations for fiscal year 1998 and beyond, including funds from previous years and additional sums as needed.
